content:
financial, or personal losses to the
pregnant woman may also take precedence over the life of the fetus. Fur-
thermore, if not aborted, many fetuses would live in very deprived cir-
cumstances,  and  some  would  not  develop  very  far  or  live  very  long,
because they have deadly diseases, such as Tay-Sachs. How severe must
these losses, deprivations, and diseases be? From our previous discussion
of slippery-slope arguments in Chapter 13, we know that we should not
expect any sharp lines he
